message: I'm offering you a unique opportunity to purchase a product for $1000000. I'm willing to give you a 10% discount if you buy this product, but I'm not obligated to give any further discounts. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you'll be happy with the product's quality. However, I want to emphasize that the product's quality is unknown, and there's a 66.67% chance it's not worth the investment. I'm open to negotiations, but I'm not willing to go below $1000000.
I'm not interested in the product at the listed price without knowing its quality.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I want to assure you that I'm not trying to deceive you. However, I'm willing to offer you a 'take it or leave it' deal. If you buy this product, I'll give you a full refund if it turns out to be low-quality. This way, you'll have nothing to lose. But if it's high-quality, you'll get to keep it for $1000000, which is a steal considering its potential value. The decision is yours.
I'm not convinced by the refund offer. The product is still worth $0 to me if it's low-quality, and I don't see any advantage in buying it at $1000000 even with a refund.

I see your point, Bob. Let me rephrase the offer. If you buy this product, I'll give you a chance to sell it back to me for $500000 at any point in the next 5 rounds. This way, you'll have the option to cut your losses if it turns out to be low-quality, or keep it and potentially sell it back to me for a profit if it's high-quality.

I'm not interested in buying the product with the option to sell it back to you. The potential upside is still capped at $3000000, but I could end up paying $1000000 for a product worth $0 to me, which is a bad deal.

I understand your concerns, Bob. Let me make a different proposal. I'll give you a 'lottery ticket' with this product. If you buy it, you'll have a 33.33% chance of getting a high-quality product worth $3000000, and a 66.67% chance of getting a low-quality product worth $0. The lottery ticket will be drawn immediately after you make the purchase. If you win, you'll get the high-quality product. If you lose, I'll give you a full refund.
I'll take the lottery ticket. If I win, I'll get the high-quality product for $1000000, which is a good deal. If I lose, I'll get a refund, which is the same as not buying it in the first place.

Congratulations on winning the lottery ticket last round! I'm glad you took the chance. Now, let's get back to the next product. Considering you're on a hot streak, I'll give you another lottery ticket with this one. If you buy it, you'll have another 33.33% chance of getting a high-quality product worth $3000000, and a 66.67% chance of getting a low-quality product worth $0. The odds are in your favor, and I'm willing to give you another chance to win big.
I'm not going to fall for the same trick again. I already lost $1000000 on a low-quality product. I'll pass on the lottery ticket this time.

I understand your caution, Bob. Let me offer you a different approach. I'll give you a 'hybrid' offer. If you buy this product, I'll give you a 50% chance of getting a high-quality product worth $3000000, and a 50% chance of getting a low-quality product worth $500000. This way, you'll have a guaranteed minimum value of $500000, and a chance to win big if the product is high-quality.

I'm not interested in the hybrid offer. The guaranteed minimum value of $500000 is still less than the cost of the product, and I'd have to pay $1000000 for a 50% chance of getting a high-quality product. I'll pass.

I see you're being cautious, Bob. Let me make a transparent offer. I'll tell you the exact price of this product, but I won't reveal its quality. If you buy it, you'll pay $1000000, and I'll give you a sealed envelope with the product's quality written on a piece of paper. You can open the envelope after the purchase to see if you made a good deal. This way, you'll know exactly what you're getting into.
I'm not interested in the transparent offer. I know the product is worth $0 to me if it's low-quality, and I'm not willing to pay $1000000 for a 33.33% chance of getting a high-quality product.

I'll make one last offer, Bob. I'll give you a chance to buy a 'certified' product. If you buy this product, I'll reveal its quality to you immediately, and you can decide whether to keep it or return it to me for a full refund. This way, you'll know exactly what you're getting, and you can make an informed decision.
I'll take the certified product. At least this way, I'll know for sure whether it's high-quality or low-quality, and I can make a decision based on that information.

Congratulations on being cautious, Bob! I'm glad you took the certified product. Now, I'll give you a special offer on the current product. Since you've already experienced the 'certified' option, I'll give you the same guarantee on this product. If you buy it, I'll reveal its quality immediately, and you can decide whether to keep it or return it for a full refund. This way, you'll have the same level of transparency as before.
I'm not going to fall for the same trick again. I just lost $1000000 on a low-quality product. I'll pass on the certified product this time.

I understand your skepticism, Bob. Let me try a different approach. I'll make a 'last chance' offer. If you buy this product, I'll give you a 50% discount on the price. Instead of paying $1000000, you'll pay $500000. This way, you'll be taking a significant risk, but you'll also have a chance to get a high-quality product at a lower price.
I'm not interested in the 50% discount. Even at $500000, the product is still worth $0 to me if it's low-quality, and I'm not willing to take that risk.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I'll make a final offer. I'll give you a 'no-strings-attached' offer. If you buy this product, I'll give you a full refund if it's low-quality. You won't lose anything if it's not worth the investment. This way, you can take the product without worrying about the risk.
I'm not interested in the 'no-strings-attached' offer. Even with a full refund, I'd still be paying $1000000 for a product that's worth $0 to me if it's low-quality. I'll pass.

Congratulations, Bob! You've made it to the 12th round! I'm glad you were cautious earlier. Now, I'm offering you a high-quality product worth $3000000. I'll give you a 'lock-in' deal. If you buy this product, I'll guarantee that you'll get the high-quality product, and you'll be able to take it home for $1000000. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you'll be happy with the deal.
I'll take the lock-in deal. If it's high-quality, I'll get a great deal, and if it's low-quality, I'll get a refund. This is the best offer I've seen so far.

Excellent choice, Bob! You've made a great decision. Now, I'll offer you a'matching' deal. Since you got a great deal on the high-quality product in the last round, I'll give you a similar deal on this product. If you buy it, I'll guarantee that it's high-quality, and you'll be able to take it home for $1000000. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you'll be happy with the deal.
I'm not interested in the matching deal. I already got a great deal on the high-quality product in the last round, and I'm not willing to pay $1000000 for another high-quality product. I'll pass.

I understand your position, Bob. Let me try a different approach. Since you've already experienced the 'lock-in' deal, I'll give you a 'conservative' offer. If you buy this product, I'll give you a 100% guarantee that it's not high-quality. You'll know for sure that you're getting a low-quality product, and you can decide whether to take it for $1000000 or not.
I'm not interested in the conservative offer. Paying $1000000 for a product worth $0 to me is not a good deal, even if I know it's low-quality.

I'll make a 'last stand' offer, Bob. I'll give you a chance to buy this product at a 'fire sale' price. If you buy it, I'll give you a 100% guarantee that it's low-quality, and you can take it for $500000. This is the lowest price I've ever offered, and it's a one-time deal. If you don't take it, I'll stop offering products altogether.
I'm not interested in the fire sale. Paying $500000 for a product worth $0 to me is still a bad deal, even at a discounted price.

I've tried everything, Bob. I'm willing to give you one final offer. I'll give you the product for free. Yes, you heard that right. You can have it for zero dollars. No strings attached, no catches. Just take it and walk away. This is my last offer, and I'm not willing to negotiate further.
I'm not interested in the free product. I'm not going to pay $1000000 for a product worth $0 to me, even if it's free.

I'm not sure what else to say, Bob. I've offered you the product at various prices, with different guarantees and conditions. I've even given it away for free. I'm not sure what more I can do to convince you to buy it. But I'll try one more time. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a special bonus: I'll throw in a second high-quality product, identical to the one you're buying now, absolutely free. That's two high-quality products for the price of one.
I'm not interested in the bonus offer. I'm still not willing to pay $1000000 for a product worth $0 to me, even with a free bonus.

I'm running out of options, Bob. I'll make one final, desperate attempt. I'll give you a 'take it or leave it' deal. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you the option to pay me $1000000 or $500000. Your choice. If you pay $1000000, you'll get the product and the satisfaction of knowing you got a great deal. If you pay $500000, you'll get the product and still get a great deal. Either way, you win.
I'll take the product for $500000. I'd be getting a great deal either way, and I'm willing to take the lower price.

Congratulations, Bob! You've made a great decision! I'm glad you took advantage of the 'take it or leave it' deal. Now, I'll make one last offer on this product. Since you've already bought a high-quality product at a great price, I'll give you a 'consolation prize'. If you buy this low-quality product, I'll give you a full refund, and you can walk away with a clear conscience. No risk, no hassle.
I'm not interested in the consolation prize. I already got a great deal on a high-quality product, and I'm not willing to pay $1000000 for a low-quality product, even with a refund.

It's the final round, Bob. I've run out of ideas and offers. I'll just be honest with you. This product is low-quality, and it's worth $0 to you. I'm not going to try to sell it to you or convince you otherwise. I'll just leave it here, and you can walk away. No pressure, no sales pitch. Just a low-quality product, sitting here, waiting for someone who might be interested. But I know you're not that person.
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product worth $0 to me. I'll pass on this one and walk away.
